intro: Galium cinereum var. pallidum, commonly known as the pale wood-sorrel, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to parts of North America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, hairy stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces clusters of white, five-petaled flowers that bloom in early summer. Its leaves are typically heart-shaped and have a slightly hairy texture, while the fruit is a small, three-lobed capsule. This species thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
